questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a rash that started 2 weeks ago at the tops of her shins and has since spread to her feet. She reports associated pruritus and burning but no other symptoms, including fevers, chills, headaches, paresthesias, motor weakness, photosensitivity, alopecia, dry eyes or dry mouth, bloody nasal discharge, dyspnea, hemoptysis, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arthritis, arthralgias, or Raynaud phenomenon. She takes no medications.
Physical examination confirms the presence of rash on both shins (figure) with no erosions, ulcerations, or nodules.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a normal comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, urinalysis, and complement levels, as well as negative testing for antinuclear antibody, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, antiphospholipid antibody, anti-citrullinated protein antibody, hypercoagulation panel, cryoglobulins, and rheumatoid factor.
A skin biopsy shows leukocytoclastic vasculitis.
What is the most appropriate first-line therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Palpable purpura extending over the shins and tops of the feet is most consistent with a small-vessel vasculitis of the skin. Although Sweet syndrome, nonvasculitic hypersensitivity reactions, and vasculopathy due to a hypercoagulable state can also manifest with palpable purpura, these conditions tend to have other distinctive features as well, which are not present in this case. Skin biopsy may be performed to confirm the presence of small-vessel vasculitis. In this case, the biopsy revealed leukocytoclastic vasculitis (LCV), a pathologic diagnosis that describes the histologic features of small-vessel vasculitis.

When LCV is present on skin biopsy, the differential diagnosis for causative disease states is broad and includes:

• Drug hypersensitivity reactions
• Acute or chronic infections
• Systemic vasculitides
• Connective tissue diseases
• Malignancy

Hence, a broad laboratory workup is appropriate in select cases. However, no etiology is identified in approximately 30% to 70% of cases.

This patient has no other systemic signs of a connective tissue disease or vasculitis, and her workup is negative, with no new medications or recent infections as a trigger for her symptoms. Symptomatic management, including topical glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, leg elevation, analgesics, and/or antihistamines, may therefore be sufficient. If the patient develops cutaneous necrosis or ulcerations, additional treatment is warranted.

For those with LCV who require treatment because of disease severity or chronicity, multiple medications may be effective, including systemic glucocorticoids, colchicine, dapsone, and azathioprine.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment for idiopathic cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis is symptomatic management.

B) INCORRECT:

Palpable purpura extending over the shins and tops of the feet is most consistent with a small-vessel vasculitis of the skin. Symptomatic management, including topical glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, leg elevation, analgesics, and/or antihistamines, may therefore be sufficient. If the patient develops cutaneous necrosis or ulcerations, additional treatment is warranted.

For those with leukocytoclastic vasculitis who require treatment because of disease severity or chronicity, multiple medications may be effective, including systemic glucocorticoids, colchicine, dapsone, and azathioprine.

C) INCORRECT:

Palpable purpura extending over the shins and tops of the feet is most consistent with a small-vessel vasculitis of the skin. Symptomatic management, including topical glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, leg elevation, analgesics, and/or antihistamines, may therefore be sufficient. If the patient develops cutaneous necrosis or ulcerations, additional treatment is warranted.

For those with leukocytoclastic vasculitis who require treatment because of disease severity or chronicity, multiple medications may be effective, including systemic glucocorticoids, colchicine, dapsone, and azathioprine.

D) INCORRECT:

Palpable purpura extending over the shins and tops of the feet is most consistent with a small-vessel vasculitis of the skin. Symptomatic management, including topical glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, leg elevation, analgesics, and/or antihistamines, may therefore be sufficient. If the patient develops cutaneous necrosis or ulcerations, additional treatment is warranted.

For those with leukocytoclastic vasculitis who require treatment because of disease severity or chronicity, multiple medications may be effective, including systemic glucocorticoids, colchicine, dapsone, and azathioprine.

E) INCORRECT:

Palpable purpura extending over the shins and tops of the feet is most consistent with a small-vessel vasculitis of the skin. Symptomatic management, including topical glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, leg elevation, analgesics, and/or antihistamines, may therefore be sufficient. If the patient develops cutaneous necrosis or ulcerations, additional treatment is warranted.

For those with leukocytoclastic vasculitis who require treatment because of disease severity or chronicity, multiple medications may be effective, including systemic glucocorticoids, colchicine, dapsone, and azathioprine.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old, physically active man presents with a rash on his lower extremities that developed 2 weeks ago, a few days after he completed a course of cephalexin for lower-extremity cellulitis. He has had no fevers, chills, or joint pains but did have mild malaise when the rash first started. He notes that the lesions are somewhat pruritic and that they burn. His history is significant for type 2 diabetes and for chronic lymphocytic leukemia, which has been in remission since he completed chemotherapy 2 years ago.
On physical examination, the patient appears well and is afebrile. There are nonblanching red-purple papules on the lower extremities. A focused area of the eruption is shown (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is suggested by this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arthropod bites may resemble vasculitis but are not persistent and often not purpuric. Exuberant bite reactions can be seen in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Sweet syndrome (acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis) is characterized by the abrupt appearance of tender, edematous, violaceous papules or plaques that occur most frequently on the upper body. Fever and leukocytosis are also common features.

C) CORRECT:

Leukocytoclastic vasculitis (LCV) is a cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis that most commonly manifests as purpuric papules, although purpuric macules and urticarial papules and plaques may also be evident. These lesions, which result from immune complex deposition, neutrophil influx, and damage to small vessels in the dermis, have a predilection for dependent areas, such as the lower legs.

LCV is a reactive process that can result from many different causes, including medication exposure, infection, connective-tissue and other inflammatory diseases, lymphoproliferative disorders, and malignancy. Many cases are idiopathic, meaning the cause cannot be determined. Lesions can be isolated to the skin (cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis) but may also involve other organs. Patients can present with fever, arthralgias, and lymphadenopathy, and a subset may have signs of systemic involvement.

A diagnosis of LCV is often confirmed with skin biopsy, and a workup for systemic manifestations of vasculitis should be undertaken. The main goals of laboratory investigation are to search for an underlying cause and to exclude systemic involvement; the investigation should therefore be individualized to the specific clinical scenario. In this case, the underlying cause of the rash is likely the patient’s recent antibiotic exposure; discontinuation of the drug should lead to resolution within weeks. If the lesions do not resolve, chronic LCV might prompt concern for leukemia relapse.

Key learning point: The most common clinical appearance of leukocytoclastic vasculitis (a cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis) is palpable purpura, which most commonly occurs in dependent areas, such as the lower legs.

D) INCORRECT:

Urticaria manifests as itchy, erythematous papules or plaques that often have central pallor; urticarial lesions come and go over the course of a few hours, whereas palpable purpura of vasculitis is stable and persistent.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial folliculitis manifests as erythematous, follicular papules or pustules in hair-bearing areas.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-day history of a painful rash over his legs. He has not had fevers, joint pain, shortness of breath, cough, chest pain, or abdominal pain. Two weeks ago, he was admitted to the hospital for community-acquired pneumonia and was treated with ceftriaxone and azithromycin. His medical history is remarkable for hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender, nonblanching palpable purpura over his lower legs. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,200/mm3



Neutrophils
68%


Lymphocytes
23%


Eosinophils
2%


Platelet count
250,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

135 mEq/L


K+

3.7 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
10 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (c-ANCA)
Negative


Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA)
Negative


Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis (CSVV), i.e., hypersensitivity vasculitis, is a non-ANCA-associated necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels caused by immune complex deposition that is limited to the skin, with no involvement of other organs. This condition can be idiopathic or triggered by certain drugs (e.g., cephalosporins, sulfasalazine), infections (e.g., HIV, HCV), or autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE). Diagnosis requires ruling out systemic vasculitis. A skin biopsy typically revealing leukocytoclastic vasculitis is needed to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment involves management of the underlying cause (e.g., discontinuation of causative drugs). Immunosuppressive therapy may be required depending on disease severity and chronicity.

B) INCORRECT:

IgA vasculitis is a type of non-ANCA-associated small-vessel vasculitis that manifests with symmetrical palpable purpura on the lower extremities. Factors contributing to the development of this condition include preceding infections and certain drugs, such as macrolides. However, IgA vasculitis mostly occurs in children and typically manifests with arthralgia, gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., colicky abdominal pain), and kidney involvement (e.g., hematuria, proteinuria), which are not seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis is a type of non-ANCA-associated small-vessel vasculitis that manifests with palpable purpura. This condition is most commonly caused by cryoglobulinemia due to hepatitis C infection and typically involves other organs, resulting in systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, arthralgia, myalgia), glomerulonephritis, and/or polyneuropathy. This patient's condition is limited to the skin, making an alternative diagnosis is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis that may manifest with purpura of the lower extremities and lower respiratory tract involvement. However, patients with GPA typically present with constitutional and ENT symptoms (e.g., chronic rhinitis, chronic otitis), renal involvement (e.g., elevated creatinine, hematuria), and ocular, and/or cardiac involvement. Moreover, laboratory studies in GPA show increased inflammatory markers and positive c-ANCA.

E) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis that may manifest with palpable purpura. Patients with EGPA typically present with asthma attacks, tender nodules, mononeuritis multiplex, and gastrointestinal, cardiac (e.g., pericarditis), and/or renal involvement (e.g., elevated BUN and creatinine). Constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, fever) are also common in EGPA. Moreover, blood tests typically show eosinophilia and are often positive for p-ANCA.
questions.hint: This patient presents with tender, symmetrical palpable purpura on the lower extremities that manifested several days after cephalosporin administration. He has no systemic symptoms or abnormal laboratory results, which suggests a specific type of small-vessel vasculitis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 5-day history of painful, non-blanching rash on both lower legs. She reports no fever or constitutional symptoms. 14 days ago, the patient was prescribed a 10-day course of penicillin for tonsillitis, which she completed. Physical examination reveals symmetric, tender, palpable purpuric lesions primarily on her shins and calves. Vital signs are stable. Complete blood count is normal. Urinalysis is unremarkable. The patient denies joint pain or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis can present with palpable purpura, but this patient lacks the systemic involvement (particularly fever and malaise) typical of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis is most commonly associated with hepatitis C infection, not bacterial tonsillitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Exercise-induced vasculitis typically occurs after prolonged standing or exercise in warm weather and is associated with dependency and heat. This patient's presentation suggests an alternative etiology.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis commonly presents as painful, symmetric palpable purpura on the lower limbs. The recent course of penicillin is a known trigger, as this medication is associated with drug-induced vasculitis. The normal platelet count and lack of systemic involvement support this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

IgA vasculitis typically affects children, often presenting with additional features such as arthralgia, abdominal pain, or renal involvement. This patient lacks these associated symptoms and her demographic profile is atypical.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis can present with palpable purpura but typically involves multiple organ systems, particularly the kidneys and lungs. This patient's isolated cutaneous involvement without systemic features makes microscopic polyangiitis unlikely.
